item.title: Congress Gears Up to Pass $900 Billion Defense Policy Bill
item.description: Lawmakers aim to send the bill, which authorizes $8 billion more than the White House requested, to the president’s desk by the end of the year.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Mike Rogers, Republican of Alabama, at a hearing earlier this year. Mr. Rogers, the House Armed Services Committee chairman, said he was eager to send the legislation to President Trump’s desk.

item.title: Trump Blasts Henry Cuellar, Democrat Lawmaker, for Not Switching Parties After Pardon
item.description: Days after pardoning him, President Trump accused Representative Henry Cuellar of Texas of disloyalty for not switching to the Republican Party.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: Representative Henry Cuellar, who received a pardon from President Trump, is running for re-election as a Democrat.

item.title: Trump Hosts the Kennedy Center Honors, Breaking Tradition
item.description: Past presidents have attended the marquee event, but on Sunday Mr. Trump was the first to host it, putting his cultural takeover of Washington in sharp relief.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Valerie Plesch for The New York Times

item.title: Democrats Call for Releasing Video of Deadly Boat Strike in the Caribbean
item.description: Top Democratic lawmakers who have seen the footage said Sunday that making the video public would provide transparency around the strikes that killed two survivors on Sept. 2.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Jim Himes said that the two survivors “were barely alive, much less engaging in hostilities.”

item.title: Superpower Competition: The Missing Chapter in Trump’s Security Strategy
item.description: President Trump is shifting from discussion of the long-lasting competition among the world’s biggest economies and nuclear powers.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: President Trump will meet with Xi Jinping, China’s leader, in Beijing in April.

item.title: Presidential Power Gets Tested Before Supreme Court After Long Conservative Project to Shrink Agencies
item.description: President Trump has repeatedly ousted leaders of independent agencies despite federal laws meant to shield those regulators from politics.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.media:description: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and other conservatives on the Supreme Court have embraced the so-called unitary executive theory, which holds that the Constitution vests all executive power in the president and that he must be able to control everything the executive branch does.

item.title: The Impact of Trump’s Slipping Approval Rating
item.description: After months of holding steady, President Trump‘s approval rating has dipped over the past several weeks, according to a New York Times analysis of public polling.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager, Claire Hogan, Whitney Shefte and Stephanie Swart

item.title: For Landmark Test of Executive Power, Echoes of a 1930s Supreme Court Battle
item.description: Franklin D. Roosevelt’s efforts to oust a Federal Trade Commission leader offer parallels to the current fight over President Trump’s actions.
item.dc:creator: Abbie VanSickle
item.media:description: The battle between William E. Humphrey and Franklin D. Roosevelt has resurfaced in a blockbuster case the Supreme Court will hear on Monday,

item.title: 4 Takeaways From The Times’s Reporting on Biden’s Immigration Record
item.description: A New York Times review of President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s actions on immigration showed that they created an opening for a more aggressive Trump administration agenda.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Customs and Border Protection agents taking migrants to be processed at a detention center in Jacumba, Calif., in 2023.

item.title: A Small Illinois City at the Center of a Seismic Shift in Abortion Access
item.description: Carbondale, Ill., a liberal enclave within driving distance of 10 states with abortion bans, has become a hub for the procedure. Last year there were nearly 11,000 abortions in this city of 21,000.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Williamson and Julia Rendleman
item.category: Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organization (Supreme Court Decision)
item.media:credit: Julia Rendleman for The New York Times

item.title: How Biden Lost Americans’ Faith in Immigration
item.description: The Democratic president and his top advisers rejected recommendations that could have eased the border crisis that helped return Donald Trump to the White House.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: People crossing the International Bridge from Matamoros, Mexico, into Texas in August 2021.

item.title: Judge Stalls Justice Dept. Effort to Seek New Comey Indictment
item.description: The judge’s decision prevented the government until at least next Friday from having access to much of the evidence it used to secure its original indictment against Mr. Comey.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.media:description: A federal judge temporarily blocked the Justice Department from using evidence in its efforts to seek a new indictment against James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director.

item.title: Hegseth Skirts Questions About Releasing Video of Sept. 2 Boat Attack
item.description: At an appearance in California, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth was noncommittal about releasing the full video of a U.S. military attack on a boat in the Caribbean.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth at the Reagan National Defense Forum in Simi Valley, Calif., on Saturday.

item.title: Trump Administration Waives $11 Million Southwest Airlines Fine
item.description: The penalty was part of a fine imposed by the Biden administration after it determined the airline had failed to provide prompt customer service and refunds to passengers in 2022.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella
item.media:credit: Taylor Glascock for The New York Times
item.media:description: The $11 million penalty that the Trump administration said it would waive was part of a $140 million fine that the Biden administration imposed in 2023.

item.title: Afrikaner Access Soars Amid Trump’s Policy Shift
item.description: The white descendants of Europeans who colonized the country are getting greater access to American officials this year, both in Washington and in Pretoria.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: White South Africans rallied in support of President Trump in February outside the U.S. Embassy in Pretoria, South Africa.

item.title: Under RFK Jr., U.S. Vaccine Policy Arrives at a ‘Defining Moment’
item.description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. may be only beginning to put his stamp on American immunization policy.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the health secretary, has methodically laid the groundwork to overhaul American vaccine policy.

item.title: Judge Rules Trump Exceeded Authority by Holding Deportees at Guantánamo
item.description: Judge Sparkle L. Sooknanan stopped short of ordering the shuttering of the detention operation. But a lawyer for the challengers said they would soon seek a closure order.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.media:description: Deportees from El Paso being transported to Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, on a military cargo plane early this year.

item.title: Running Out of Time, Republicans in Congress Still Lack a Health Plan
item.description: Top Republicans have said they want to produce a proposal in short order to counter Democrats pressing for an extension of health care subsidies. They have not gotten far.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:description: Senator Tim Scott at the Capitol earlier this year.

item.title: Trump’s Security Strategy Focuses on Profit, Not Spreading Democracy
item.description: President Trump’s new National Security Strategy describes a country that is focused on doing business and reducing migration while avoiding passing judgment on authoritarians.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump at the White House last month. The National Security Strategy his administration released describes a world in which American interests are far narrower than how prior administrations — even in his first term — had portrayed them.

item.title: The Supreme Court, Once Wary of Partisan Gerrymandering, Goes All In
item.description: The court’s conservative majority said that Texas’ asserted political motives justified letting the state use voting maps meant to disadvantage Democrats in the midterms.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:description: A map of Texas’ congressional districts during a hearing in Austin in August.
